clinical_study.brief_title: Resident Observed Burnout After Daily Supplementation With Coffee
clinical_study.official_title: Resident Observed Burnout After Daily Supplementation With Coffee

lead_sponsor.agency: New York University School of Medicine

clinical_study.source: New York University School of Medicine

brief_summary.textblock: Coffee drinking is frequently reported as a negative outcome in studies on burnout, but the effect of an increased coffee intake on resident burnout has not been reported in the literature. This study is a prospective, interventional cohort study enrolling up to 50 residents from the Internal Medicine Residency Program to look at the relationship between coffee and resident burnout.

detailed_description.textblock: Resident burnout is increasingly being recognized as detrimental to both physician well being and patient care. It has been linked to an increased rate of medical errors and a reduced quality of patient care. In addition, there have been multiple high-profile physician suicides in the past years. This has resulted in a renewed focus on physician mental health and workload.

primary_outcome.description: 14 question survey measuring number of cups of coffee and level of exhaustion

secondary_outcome.measure: Coffee consumption measured by self reporting questionaire

secondary_outcome.description: 14 question survey with questions measuring emotional wellbeing
14 question survey with questions measuring feelings of self value

arm_group.description: effect of supplying Internal Medicine residents at NYU with free coffee on self reported features of psychological health, energy and burnout

intervention.description: At the beginning of study week 2 (study day 8), two coffee machines (one Nespresso Inissia and one Hamilton Beach 46205 12 Cup Programmable Coffee Maker) will be installed in the resident work rooms at each site. Subjects will be provided with free coffee beans, milk, cream, sugar and sweetener

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- A resident in the NYU Internal Medicine residency program
Exclusion Criteria:
- Allergy or intolerance to coffee or caffeine
- Pregnancy
